awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying precipitation changes in the South American subtropics over the late Pleistocene
awd_abstract_narration:
Many regions of the world, including the Americas, are experiencing drought and its political consequences.  The critical question is why, and are the causes natural or man-made?  The answer to this and other questions will help us plan for what is ahead, as some regions of the planet continue to warm and dry.  This project will focus on the central Andes of South America- a region that is both politically fragile and recently drought stricken. The aim is to study the interplay of temperature and drought in the past, for clues to their probable connections in the future. 

The main purpose of the project is to create a map of changes in the sizes of ancient lakes in the central Andes, giant ancestors to modern lakes in the region such as Lake Titicaca. Well-preserved shorelines mark the extent of these ancient lakes, and using state-of-the art techniques, the age of these features can be determined. The mapping and dating is vital to relating lake size (and therefore rainfall amounts in the past) to the changing temperature state of the planet, which is well known from other records.  In short, these reconstructions will help scientists to better understand how rainfall in this region will change in the coming decades to centuries.

This award is cofunded by the Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the mechanisms controlling water availability in the world’s drylands, where habitability is governed by water supply, has become a critical priority for climate scientists. In the past fifty years, the Central Andes of South America has experienced decreases in stream flow and water availability that appear anomalous over the last 600 years, with substantial impacts on Andean populations. Unfortunately, the scarcity of climate and hydrological data in this remote area has hampered efforts to understand its response to future climate variability.

This project aimed to improve forecasts of future hydrological change by reconstructing the impact of past climate changes on water availability in the region. Shoreline deposits in lake basins throughout the Central Andes indicate dramatic increases in lake sizes in response to past climate changes. In this project, we mapped lake shoreline deposits along a 1300-km north-south transect from northern Chile to central Argentina to determine the size of past lake expansions. We also determined the ages of these deposits by precise measurements of naturally occurring uranium and thorium isotopes; these ages allowed us to identify the climatic conditions that led to lake expansions.

These lake-based estimates of past hydrological changes demonstrate that water availability throughout this arid region reached its maximum during the end of the last ice age, approximately 16,000 to 11,000 years ago. This period was marked by dramatic changes in ocean and atmospheric circulation that altered sea surface temperatures in both the Atlantic and Pacific, with impacts on the intensity of the South American summer monsoon. Our results provide some of the first precisely dated records of past hydrological changes from this water-stressed region, and they lay the foundation for testing whether the climate models used to forecast future changes are able to reproduce the magnitude and drivers of past changes.

This project provided extensive training for a female Ph.D. student whose thesis focused on this work. Three undergraduates have also been involved in sample preparation and analysis at MIT and have been mentored by the Ph.D. student; the undergraduates gained experience with laboratory research, while the Ph.D. student developed very strong mentoring skills. Results were presented to the scientific community at multiple international conferences and university seminars. The project was shared with students in a video broadcast into classrooms, and with the general public in an event at the Boston Public Library hosted by NOVA and WGBH. Research related to the award has also been featured on the National Geographic website and in the National Geographic Kids' Almanac 2020.
